resources.string:
Welcome!
This isn’t an OS, a virtual machine or a screenshot, and it’s not just a website. It’s a handcrafted simulation of a desktop environment, built from scratch.
No templates. No frameworks. Just Kotlin, Compose Multiplatform, love and care, running fully in your browser.
You can double-click the icons on the left to open apps. Each one shows a piece of me: my projects, skills, story, and work.
There’s no onboarding, no instructions. Explore it as you would a real OS. Think of it as a tiny operating system... one that boots into who I am.
This is me, in code.
Thank you for visiting.
— kosail
Change the color theme on dotfolio and its apps
Choose your preferred background image for your system
A minimalist, interactive, Windows 11 themed developer portfolio built with Compose Multiplatform. Designed to speak clearly, cleanly, and with purpose.
But dotfolio is not a website. It’s a window to who I am.
It was built entirely with Kotlin and Compose Multiplatform. Powered by Compose for Web (WASM/JS), and tested on Arch Linux, of course.
Wherever you are now, I wish you the best, my lovely kitty.
ドットフォリオへようこそ

I build things with intent. This is my desktop, my quiet craft. Every pixel was placed with care.
I built dotfolio not to impress, but to express.
Welcome, fellow programmer! You are very welcome to visit every corner of this blog, this personal space. I hope you can get an idea of me, and get the beats of the heart that wrote these posts.
Screenshot of my blog, time ago

I once had a blog (or well said, I ran a blog for 4 years). It was called Mi lugar en el mundo (roughly translated as "My place in this world"). First on Tumblr, later on WordPress. I'll relaunch it in the future, maybe using Hugo (the static site generators written in Go) since I loved the simplicity of Markdown.
Manga panel from Oyasumi Punpun, by Asano Inio.

Oyasumi Punpun is one of the bests mangas I have ever read. Not because of the story, but Tanaka Aiko resonates deeply inside me.
Manga panel from Oyasumi Punpun, by Asano Inio.
Screenshot of one of Takayan's songs on YouTube

It’s strange to think that eight long years have passed since I began studying Japanese—time slipping by so fast. I haven’t reached the highest level I once imagined I would by now.
I’ve become a man. Older, stronger. Yet with little time left for myself.
I wish I could go back. Get my hands dirty more often. Do things without doubting whether “I” could pull them off. Worry less about others. Worry less about myself.
Even now, as a man—even with half of me made of regrets for the distant past—when I close my eyes and listen to old Takayan songs, I find myself grateful. Grateful for that silly kid who decided, all those years ago, to learn Japanese.
This afternoon is for you. For your sweetness. For the shimmering voyage of your smile.
I know you may have one, and this contact box actually works. Please reply either in English, Spanish, or Japanese only.
Are you a Kotlin fan? Or why did you choose it over JavaScript to build your portfolio?

Lately my favorite language is Kotlin, but I'm not a fan. Let me explain:
I came from a Java background, so it felt like a natural upgrade. The same JVM under the hood but with built-in null safety, coroutines for smooth async, and (my favorite) Compose Multiplatform for writing one UI that actually runs on desktop, mobile, and web.
That said, I don’t believe in golden hammers. Kotlin is great for apps, but it’s not what I reach for when I want to go low-level or mess with things like root services. For that, I’ve always had a soft spot for Go and C (it’s tough love tho, I just wish strings mem allocs in C didn’t feel like punishment).
Then there’s JavaScript. I honestly hated it. It's not personal, but I prefer predictability and strong typing over something that Promise me <any>, and at the moment of truth it returns an undefined. TypeScript, however, felt like a game changer, and along with React, it became a stack that I truly liked. But why I didn't use JS or TS for this project? Because I knew nothing from web dev aside from the triad by the moment I created dotfolio, and that's why I used Kotlin over conventional web tools.
So yeah, I jump between stacks depending on the job. Languages are tools, and I don’t mind switching between screwdrivers and hammers as long as I’m building something useful. I care more about the craft, not the tools.
Why build your own "OS" instead of using a traditional portfolio?

Because a portfolio shouldn't feel like a résumé. It should feel like stepping into my brain. I didn’t want static links or an endless talk about "how great I am" or how I'm so confident about my skills, because I'm not. I wanted something playful, interactive, and deeply mine. A technical challenge to myself to prove you, and me, what I'm capable of.

When people hear that I'm from Honduras I often get asked for Honduras delicacies, and I always talk about Baleadas.
Oh man, a baleada is like a warm, comforting hug from Honduran street food. It's a soft, fluffy flour tortilla, fresh off the comal, stuffed with creamy refried beans, crumbled semi-seco cheese, and a drizzle of sweet-savory mantequilla (Honduran sour cream).
The classic version is simple but so satisfying, though you can level it up with scrambled eggs, avocado, or even sliced plantains. Fold it in half, take a bite, and boom! Pure happiness (at least for me).
I often find myself with a fuzzy feeling when I think of home and its cuisine.
What thing you could not live without?

Nature. I wouldn’t make it far without it.
I’m not a hiker. I’m not outdoorsy. But touching soil and standing quietly in front of a deep green forest... it resets something. It’s not about escaping tech. It’s about remembering how to breathe.
I’m kosail — a computer science student from Honduras who found their path through Linux and making custom roms for Android, over a decade ago. I’ve been exploring ever since.

I’ve always preferred clean UIs over cluttered dashboards. Tools that feel quiet, stable, and focused. Like home, even on first use.
I believe software should be carefully crafted: apps should be fast to load, pleasant to look at, and invisible when not needed. Its not just UI, but UX.
I’m not a genius. But I care deeply about what I build.
Personally, I’ll keep building the kind of tools I wish existed. Minimalist. Meaningful. Mostly on Linux, and powered by Compose Multiplatform and Go.
Professionally, I work with TypeScript and React to build fast, pragmatic enterprise tools. However, I may be transition to NextJS in the future.
In both paths, my focus is the same: to grow in full stack development, bring my own SaaS ideas to life as clean, sustainable, and cross-platform software that lasts.
Click on the icons to see more
A clean, native control center for Lenovo laptops — built for Linux.

This was the first real-world app I ever made — and it came from real frustration.
On Windows, Lenovo laptops have official tools to control performance modes, battery conservation, and rapid charging. On Linux? Nothing usable. So I made my own.
KVantage is a sleek desktop app that brings these essential hardware toggles to Lenovo Linux users. Inspired by GNOME and GTK's clean visuals, it focuses only on the features that matter — no ads, no clutter, no distractions. Just control.

Everything.
• The GUI was built from scratch using Kotlin and Compose Multiplatform for Desktop • The backend is a secure, root-privileged Go daemon I wrote myself, handling ACPI read/write through /proc/acpi/call • I created a custom IPC protocol (text-based, CLI-style) for communication between the GUI and daemon • The app runs with regular user privileges. Only the tiny backend runs as root, for safety • It supports multiple performance profiles, battery threshold toggles, rapid charge, and even multi-language theming
There is no official API for these features. All of it is achieved through low-level kernel interfaces (ACPI), usually hidden from standard users. I had to learn how they work, how to invoke them, and how to wrap them into a safe, graphical experience.
The hardest and most beautiful thing I’ve ever built.

Dotfolio recreates the feel of a full desktop environment: apps you can drag, windows you can open and close, a real clock ticking in the taskbar. It looks like an operating system, but it’s not. It’s an interactive story about me, told through software.
Everything here is handcrafted in Kotlin using Compose Multiplatform, all inside a single-page WebAssembly app. There are no UI libraries, no templates, and no backend. Every pixel, every component, every interaction is custom-made.
From the window manager to the animated taskbar, from real-time state tracking to theming logic — I built it all. Even features like z-indexing (bringing a window to front when clicked) are handled through my own lightweight renderer logic.
Dotfolio doesn’t try to imitate Windows — it uses its language to speak mine. Each app here reveals a part of who I am: my projects, values, writing, voice.
It was never meant to be “just a portfolio.” It’s a living proof of concept, one that shows what I can do when given space and intent. What you see —and what you feel— was built with care, not copied from a template.
I hope it speaks for itself.
A calm soundscape, rebuilt to flow across platforms.

Blanket was the spark. A quiet little app on Linux that filled the room with rain, fire, and birdsong. It was created by Rafael Mardojai, who's part of the GNOME Circle, and I loved its simplicity.
While beautiful, it was bound to one desktop: Linux. It is true that there are forks of it (which you can find in the app GitHub repository), but I feel like they didn't capture the aesthetics and the love that Rafael placed into Blanket. Aria is my tribute to it.
I rebuilt it from scratch in Kotlin with Compose Multiplatform, so it could live not only on Linux, but also on Windows, macOS, and the web. The design borrows GTK’s elegance, but it speaks with my own voice.
Like the original, Aria has no accounts, no ads, no clutter. Just nature’s sounds — mix them, adjust them, let them fade away as you rest or work. A rewrite often means adding more, but this one is different: Aria isn’t about more features. It’s about preserving the calm and carrying it everywhere without breaking its spirit.
Under the hood, the web version relies only on the browser’s native audio API. The JVM version uses Korau — the audio engine of KorGE, Kotlin Game Engine — because Java’s built-in audio wasn’t enough. I needed something modern, fast, and precise to let the sounds breathe.
Soon, when it’s complete, I’ll link it here. For now, you can follow its progress on GitHub below.

Thanks for visiting Dotfolio! If something here resonated, or if you’d like to say hello, I’d love to hear from you.
The best way is through the message window in the FAQ section. Or, feel free to reach out by email: [ %1$d ] That’s it. No social media. No noise.

This page doesn’t explain anything.
It just shows you what feels right to me — visually, emotionally, aesthetically.
A quiet corner for pixels I find beautiful, and that inspires me how to design and build.
Dotfolio is designed for desktop. Try visiting from a larger screen to explore it fully.

This is a simplified view of Dotfolio, designed for smaller screens. For the full desktop simulation, try a larger device.
